resource.name: finite_element_analysis_definition_relationships
resource.name.french: Rapports entre les définitions d'analyses des éléments finis
resource.keywords: resource, finite element analysis, design, PDM, idealisation, module

abstract.p: ISO 10303-107:2006 specifies the association between idealised concepts within a finite element analysis and the design definitions of those concepts. The concepts that are idealised within a finite element analysis include the action that is simulated, the states of the product, and the section properties. ISO 10303-107:2006 also specifies the association between a representation of a field that is calculated by a finite element analysis and a property of a defined state of a product.

purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application resource for the representation of product information and for the exchange of product data. The objective is to provide a neutral mechanism capable of describing products throughout their life cycle. This mechanism is suitable not only for neutral file exchange, but also as a basis for implementing and sharing product databases, and as a basis for archiving. This part of ISO 10303 is a member of the integrated application resources series. This part of ISO 10303 specifies the fea_definition_relationships_schema.
This part of ISO 10303 provides a means of associating finite element analysis information with information about the design and structure of a product. This part of ISO 10303 provides links between:

ul.li: finite element information specified by ISO 10303-104; and

both:
the product and property definition information specified by ISO 10303-41; and
the product topology information specified by ISO 10303-42.

purpose.p: These links enable the following actions to take place:

ul.li: a finite element analysis step can be linked to the design specification of the action that the finite element analysis step simulates;

purpose.note: This provides additional information about the analysis step, and a navigation route to the analysis step using a Product Data Management (PDM) system.

ul.li: a finite element analysis state can be linked to the design specification of the product state that it calculates;

purpose.note: This provides additional information about the analysis state, and a navigation route to the analysis state using a PDM system.

ul.li: a surface or curve section property can be linked to the design specification of the section;

purpose.note: This provides additional information about the section and its properties. The design specification of a variation of surface section properties with respect to position can be specified using ISO 10303-51 and ISO 10303-50.

ul.li: an FEA node, FEA element or aspect of an FEA element can be linked to the topology of a product.

purpose.note: This provides a direct link between the features of a product as identified by its CAD topology and FEA. This will enable the results from an analysis to be related to a design feature.
purpose.p:
The relationships of the schemas in this part of ISO 10303 to other schemas that define the integrated resources of this International Standard are illustrated in Figure 1 using the EXPRESS-G notation. EXPRESS-G is defined in annex D of ISO 10303-11.
Figure 1 - Schema relationships for Product and model relationship

inscope.li: an association between a set of a finite element analysis steps and the design or specification for an action;
an association between a finite element analysis state and a design or specification for a product state;
an association between a finite element analysis result and a property which is possessed by a product state;
an association between a surface or curve section property in a finite element model and a property which is possessed by a product;
an association between a node or element in a finite element model and an aspect of the topology of the product.

outscope.li: the identification or description of an action;
the identification or description of a product, or state of a product;
the identification or description of a property;
a finite element model of a product.

schema.name: product_and_model_relationships_schema
schema.introduction:
The product_and_model_relationships_schema specifies the relationship between:
an idealisation of a product as a domain of an analysis; and
a discretised model of a product for analysis.
schema.fund_cons:
Within ISO 10303, the following are separate concepts:
the design defintion of a product; The design definition of a product is recorded using ISO 10303-41.
the idealisation of a product for analysis; A single design definition can have many idealisations for analysis. The idealisations of a product for analysis can be recorded using ISO 10303-41 or using ISO 10303-53.
the discretised model of a product for analysis. An idealisation for analysis can have many discretised models created for it. The discretised model of a product for analysis can be recorded using either ISO 10303-104, or ISO 10303-53.
The ISO 10303 series of parts allows a single idealisation for analysis to be recorded in different ways, and allows a disctretised model to be recorded in different ways. This part of ISO 10303 associates a discretised model of a product with the corresponding idealisation of the product, irrespective of the way in which they are recorded.
This part of ISO 10303 can also specify that:
different records of an idealisation of a product for analysis have the same meaning; and
different records of a discretised model of a product have the same meaning.

schema.name: action_and_model_relationships_schema
schema.introduction:
The action_and_model_relationships_schema specifies the relationship between:
an idealisation of a product as a domain of an analysis; and
a discretised model of a product for analysis.
schema.fund_cons:
Within ISO the following are separate concepts:
the design definition of a product; The design definition of a product is recorded using ISO 10303-41.
the idealisation of a product for analysis; A single design definition can have many idealisations for analysis. The idealisation of a product for analysis can be recorded using ISO 10303-41.
the discretised model of a product for analysis; An idealisation for analysis can have many discretised models created for it. The discretised model of a product for analysis can be recorded using either ISO 10303-104, or ISO 10303-53.
The ISO 10303 series of parts allows a single idealisation for analysis to be recorded in different ways, and allows a discretised model to be recorded in different ways. This part of ISO 10303 associates a discretised model of a product with the corresponding idealisation of the product, irrespective of the way in which they are recorded.
This part of ISO 10303 can also specify that:
different records of an idealisation of a product for analysis have the same meaning; and
different records of a discretised model of a product have the same meaning.

schema.name: state_and_model_relationships_schema
schema.introduction:
The state_and_model_relationships schema specifies the relationship between:
an idealisation of a state as a domain of an analysis; and
a discretised model of a state for analysis.
schema.fund_cons:
Within ISO 10303, the following are separate concepts:
the design definition of a state; The design definition of a state is recorded using ISO 10303-56.
the idealisation of a state for analysis; A single design definition can have many idealisations for analysis. The idealisation for a state for analysis can be recorded using ISO 10303-56, or using ISO 10303-53.
The discretised model of a state for analysis An idealisation for analysis can have many discretised models created for it. The discretised model of a state for analysis can be recorded using either ISO 10303-104, or ISO 10303-53.
The ISO 10303 series of parts allows a single idealisation for analysis te be recorded in different ways, and allows a discretised model to be recorded in different ways. This part of ISO 10303 associates a discretised model of a state with the corresponding idealisation of the state, irrespective of the way in which they are recorded.
This part of ISO 10303 can also specify that:
different records of an idealisation of a state for analysis have the same meaning; and
different records of a discretised model of a state have the same meaning.

schema.name: property_distribution_and_model_relationships_schema
schema.introduction:
The property_distribution_and_model_relationships_schema specifies the relationship between:
a property distribution; and
a discretised model of a property distribution for numerical analysis.
schema.fund_cons:
Within ISO 10303, the following are separate concepts:
the distribution of a property over an idealised product, action or state; A property distribution over an idealised product, action or state can be recorded using ISO 10303-41, or using ISO 13030-53.
the discretised model of a property distribution for numerical analysis A property distribution can have many discretised models created for it. The discretised model of a property distribution obtained by analysis can be recorded using either ISO 10303-104, or ISO 10303-53. The ISO 10303 series of parts allows a single property distribution to be recorded in different ways, and allows a discretised model of a property distribution to be recorded in different ways. This part of ISO 10303 associates a discretised model of a property distribution with the corresponding distribution, irrespective of the way in which they are recorded.

schema.name: fea_definition_relationships_schema
schema.introduction:
The fea_definition_relationships_schema specifies relationships between the definitions of a beam or shell section property and the idealisations of these definitions for finite element analysis.
The fea_definition_relationships_schema also specifies the relationships between:
a topological region; and
a topological vertex;
and a corresponding finite element model, single finite element, or node.
schema.fund_cons: A finite element analysis is based upon an idealisation of an activity, state, property distribution, or shell or beam section. A single activity, state, property distribution, or shell or beam section can have many different idealisations that are used in, or created by, many different finite element analyses. This schema provides links between the definitions of concepts contained in ISO 10303-41, and the FEA idealisations of them contained in ISO 10303-104.
